p.s: The anti-semetic content of The Merchant of Venice raises the question whether the play fuels antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes or raises awareness for the problem of antisemitism.
Many people argue that especially after the holocaust it is not acceptable anymore to produce plays with such anti-semitic language and content.
In the Nazi era it was a favourite play and was used to make the people believe in those stereotypes.
Other offensive work, that was only reflecting the prejudices of its time has been shewed so it will not fuel antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes.

On the other hand many people argue that it raises awareness for the problem by giving historical insights in Shakespeare's time making it possible for people to recognize such hateful behaviour in their own life.
They also point out that in the play Shylock's opressors are exposed for the racists that they are.
Through the timeless theme hate, The Merchant of Venice teaches people now empathy, which defuels antisemeticanti-semetic stereotypes.
In my opinion the play can definitely do both: Itit can strengthen stereotypes but it can also draw attention to the problem.
In most modern productions Shylock is presented as the sympathetic figure, making it easy for the audience to identify with him and feel pity for him.
But the results can never be surely estimated: Thethe reaction of the audience can be quite different depending on where they are from and what they believe in.
I believe that it can be dangerous to just watch the play and not talk about it.
That is why the play should only be watched where it can be discussed and commented for example in class.
In conclusion I believe that The Merchant of Venice can raise awareness for the problem of antisemitism if it is treated with caution.
Otherwise it could achieve the opposite.
